fol.124r
Belgia 1591 3 April to my L. Trea
s
Belgia: 1591: Ap
r
May it please yo
r
good L. by
S
r
John Norris
report &
by such former l
re
s as I have writen to yo
r
L. wherof
one was of
e 18 & an oth
r
of
e 13 of
e last, I
trust yo
u
are adv
r
tized of
e
States
resolution, to
e moste
of those matters that sundry times before yo
u
required
mee to urge, & now again by
e last of
e 21 of
marche w
ch
I have lately receaved. W
th
much a doe
& more to satisfie her
Ma
ty
then for any willingnes
oth
r
wise they have yeelded heer to send 2 comp
ies
of their
owne entertainm
t
to
e
Gouverno
r
of Ostend
, w
ch
yet
they affirme to be wholy su
fluous & will condition
w
th
e gouvernor that they may be retorned when
e
forces of
e Contrey shallbee redy for
e field. How
much they have bin moved alredy & wilbee furder grieved,
that
e contribut
o
ns of those
tes shold bee oth
r
wise disposed
then they them selves shall think requesit, yo
r
L. will
consider by that w
ch
my former hath signified unto yo
u
.
For my self I will conforme my endevours to her
Hig
nes
good pleasure, but I see before hand by that
forme of proceeding w
ch
they use in other actions,
that
they will never
and by
e spetiall dislike w
ch
they
shewe in this matter, that they will nev
r
bee but Jalous,
unquiet & complaining, till they have the managing
of theyr owne, aswell in Ostend as in ev
r
y other towne
t
taineth to theyr goverment. And though in
substance
e meaning of her Ma
ty
be no oth
r
then theyrs,
not to p
r
judice their righte but to take
e best & safest way
to benefit theyr estate, yet of a naturall im
fection
they are merveilously wedded to outward formes of
ceeding & to a p
r
cise ob
s
vance of
e orders of the
contrey, & from them they will not vary for any manner
of
suasion. Yo
r
L. will vouchsafe to consider of this
matter & to give mee some notice of her Ma
ties
pleasure,
w
ch
I follow heer & furder as much as I am able.
Astouching
e
ject w
ch
yo
r
L. sent hether for disswading
this people from
e offers of peace if it be yo
r
desire to have
it published abroad, heer is no man I am certain that will
willingly print it w
th
out
e privity of
e States, and the States
fol.124v
Belgia: 1591: Ap
r
there is no dout, will alwaies suspect it to come from her Ma
ty
.
And whether it be expedient that it should be so surmised
or that
e motion of peace w
ch
is wholy quailed of yt self
should now again be stirred to frame an answere unto it
&
e people occasyoned to dispute yt to & fro, & to construe
the sufficiency of
e reasons or both sides, I submit my
self therin to yo
r
L. opinion, being redy for any thing that
yo
u
shall resolve.but oth
r
wise of my self I should
hold yt sufficient, to keep matter enough in store, & when the
time is fitt for yt, to concurr w
th
e states in delivering yt
abroad. The l
re
heerw
th
w
ch
I send unto my LL. of her
Ma
t
councell is to signify unto them how I speed about
e dets w
ch
ar owing from
e States unto
e
L. Wilughby
& in
e sollicita
o
n of those matters I found a meet opportunity
for
t
they were buisied in
e affaires of
e Admiralty to
present such matt
r
unto
em as I was lately willed by
her Ma
ty
for
e setting forth of their shippes to enconter
those of
Don
k
New
p
&
Grav
e
& such oth
r
p
r
parations
as is made of
e Liguers, To my motion therin & to
e
L. Willughbies causes they have made me
e answere
w
ch
I sent unto yo
r
L. & besech yo
u
to im
te to her Hig
nes
&
e
LL.
And to
e end yo
r
L. might receave a
fect
specifica
o
n of
e strength of al theyr shipping, that
is continually maintained for
e franchise of
e sea
aswell of
I have sent yo
u
a list of
em all, aswell of those that
ar appointed to gard
e rest of
Flandres,
as all other
plans w
ch
upon my instance to
e states was delivered unto
mee by
e Councel of
e Admiralty. For
e dets
that ar claymed by
e L. Willughby, although they know
for certain & I was willed by
e LL. to signify so much
that his L. is an earnest sutor for l
re
s of reprisall
that accordingly as his owne goodes are heer detained by
waie of arres t, so his L. might have leave for
e
recovery of such sommes as are dew unto him from
e
States to staie
e goodes wheresoever of any subject of
these contreys: yet they saie
t
such a course was nev
er
put in practise neither by her Ma
ty
nor by any
other
Prince for a private mans cause against theyr pub
lic
state. And consydering
e dangr of
e consequ
ence in
that
ceeding, & theyr infinit consumptions by
reason of
fol.125v
Belgia: 1591: Ap
r
these warres, they hope her Ma
ty
in this matter will shew no
such example for other princes to imitat. We
have c
r
tain intelligence, that 800 of
e mutined souldiers of
Diest
in
Brabant
have made an incursion into
e Land of
Liege,
and taken & spoiled
e Towne of
Huie
a strong
place upon
e Maes, upon
e mid waie upon
e river between
Namurs
&
e Towne of Liege. Ther is joyned unto it a
castel of good strength, w
th
a garrison of souldiers, w
ch
forced p
nt
ly
e Spaniard to forsake
e place. w
th
all
e
country people raised on
e suddain such forces of horse &
foote as they cutt of all
e passages between
t
& Diest
& forced
e ennemy into
Hannuyn,
w
ch
shold seem by
e
adv
r
tisem
t
given, to bee an open village toward
Brabant, in w
ch
place when
e l
re
was written they
were kept as beseiged w
th
out hope to escape. In
e
mean season it is sayd, that
e mutins of
Herentals
sent
a renforcement of oth
r
troupes into Diest.
Count
Maurice
is gon into
Zeland
intending p
nt
ly to draw
such troupes awaie from thence as may be spared for
e field.
S
r
Francis Vere
is de
ted for
Disbourgh,
w
th
co
m
ission from
e
Councel
to Joyne
w
th
Count Oversteyn
, & to employ
e forces of those
quarters to beat
e ennemy from his worke, who, as
wee are informed, have begun a fortification on
this side
e Issel over against
Deventer.
& T
but hath not yet assembled above 600 men.
& thus
I take my humble leave. From
e Hage. 3 April.
A
o
1591.
